div.p:
ryayo śrī sata
śā koṭī
namaḥś śīvăya
bhaṭāra parameśva
ra sarvvadaiva kusamvaḥhi ya
jāmiḥ Inan cīṣnāṇḍa ḍapū
nta selendranamaḥ santanū
namāṇḍa bāpaṇḍa bhadravati
namaḥṇḍa Ayaṇḍa sampūrṇa
namaṇḍa viniṇḍa selendranamaḥ
mamāgappāsarlempevāṅiḥ
sarvadaiva can be Sanskrit, sarvadā+eva ‘truly always, or it can be a slightly deviant spelling of sarvadeva ‘all gods’. The former option seems more likely in the context.

ku could equally be possessive suffix. But I take it as marking the agent of a transitive verb sembah-i, with orthographic doubling of the base-final consonant, plus glide and irrealis suffix (kusambaḥhiya = kusembahia). But Boechari assumes here hiyaṁ ‘god’, which is admittedly not a bad idea. It would give us the OM form of sembahyang. (Also attested in an OJ inscription.) At the transition between lines 5 and 6, I expect a word such as ‘relative’, to cover the group that follows. This is why I restore the word jāmi, which has precisely this sense in Sanskrit, but note that the j is conjectural, and the final ḥ implies borrowing of an inflected Sanskrit form (nom. sg.), which is a bit unusual; the final /h/ could also be explained in other ways, e.g. as a purely phonetic/graphic feature with reference to the repeated forms in °namaḥ which must mean °nāma.

I don’t get which would lurks behind cīṣnāṇḍa. Perhaps, if we may read vīṣṇāṇḍa, we can imagine here a form of Malay besan? Cf. Sungai Musi inscription published in Archipel 2011, for ayanda and bapanda.

It should be noted that if my divisions of words is correct, Selendranamaḥ is a very surprising name, from the Sanskrit point of view. Either is is for Śailendranāma ‘named Śailendra’, in which case the ḥ is unexpected; or it is for Śailendranamaḥ ‘Śailendra-homage’, in which case it makes no sense (this is not a natural Sanskrit compound). But if we separate selendra namaḥ, we seem to run into other problems.

In line 11, it would also be possible to read vājīḥ. The rest of the reading seems fairly secure. Could we have here an irrealis verb-from ma-magap-a? It is a bit reminiscent of the still unexplained maṅgap forms, mentioned in Griffiths 2011 and 2021. For the rest, I have no idea at all.
First edited by Boechari. This revised edition by Arlo Griffiths (2025) based on the EFEO estampage ... and phorogrammetry.
